> 
> At least it wasn't already on course to rendezvous with the ISS or in other word: on a collision course.

It's not like the way to reach ISS is to shoot it into an orbit which will hit ISS at high speed, then slow down at the last second. At a point where collision is a possible scenario, the relative speed is already low.
The next attempt to link with the spacecraft comes at 8:50 p.m. EDT Tuesday / 12:50 am UTC Thursday / 2:50 am CEST Thursday

With "on course to rendezvous" I meant close to the ISS.

> 
> With "on course to rendezvous" I meant close to the ISS.

Then it is slow (as I said) and so again no problem.

> 
> Is there a decent chance of regaining control?

At this point, probably not. Even if they did the craft can't make it to the ISS from what I understand. The only point now is so it doesn't make an uncontrolled re-entry.
If they do achieve control-which is admittedly pretty doubtful-the automatic rendezvous should work fine, and then they can use the TORU manual backup system for docking. It's not lost yet.

[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/russian-cargo-ship-spinning-out-of-control-in-orbit-video/](http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/russian-cargo-ship-spinning-out-of-control-in-orbit-video/)

Well... it ***is*** a Russian spacecraft... and I would think Russians speak and write Russian.

On topic:

How many Progress launches to ISS in a year?

> 
> Well... it ***is*** a Russian spacecraft... and I would think Russians speak and write Russian.
> On topic:
> 
> How many Progress launches to ISS in a year?

It's variable - current rates are a launch every 3 to 5 months.

And prior to today, all progress spacecraft have accomplished their missions except the progress M-12M in 2011 (the soyuz rocket upperstage had a malfunction for this one - so it was not a progress issue)

Now, progress use basically the same automated systems as the soyuz spacecraft - so there might be some serious verifications made before they attempt the next manned launch.

**Edited <time datetime="2015-04-28T23:51:43Z" title="04/28/2015 11:51  PM" data-short="9 yr">April 28, 2015</time> by sgt\_flyer**

The Russians have a policy of making sure they can fly the next Progress within 45 days, in case of issues like this. It's not intended to use the same launcher, so if this is ultimately the result of a launcher issue (as seems to be the Roscosmos working hypothesis) that should be fully able to go ahead.

Am I the only one thinking collision? Sensors go out on the right side, spinning- It makes sense (to me at least) that some sort of debris, whether a micro meteorite or satellite junk, clipped its right side and sent it tumbling. It's happened before.
There's not likely to be much debris at that height; anything would decay within a couple of weeks at most.
Good point. Still, you never know. But you're probably right. It could have been an explosion or a fuel tank depressurization, or something of the likes.

They didn't notice the 1.0 update, and their old ship spun out of control. Hopefully the next patch will fix that.

For now, though, they can just timewarp to stop the spin.

So, haven't checked in on here in a while. Is there any *Progress*?

Please, kill me now.
Don't have full details yet, but last pass was 'fruitless'. So far it's turning out like Phobos-Grunt in miniature.
